Also 9.9(repeating) is not 10.   Based on .9(repeating)=1 trick... (1/3)3 equals 1 even though 1/3 is expressed as .3(repeating), it's repeating because it's slightly more than each 3... at the theoretical end, infinitely far away, there is a 4... that's why it repeats.  Because it's slightly bigger than all those threes. A repeating number can't be multiplied ignoring that slightly bigger amount which changes .999... into 1.

Save your fellow man, post this everywhere.       
         
 A WARNING TO ALL THOSE BRAVE OR STUPID ENOUGH TO VISIT THE COMMENT SECTION:  Whenever you see somebody post a link, do not click it.  However, it is human nature that our curiosity often overwhelms our instincts, so here's some steps to take in case you absolutely must know what the link leads to.       
   
 1) Turn your speakers/headphones off.  Shit's most likely going to get loud, inappropriate, or both.       
 2) DO NOT just click the link.  Right click it and hit "Open Link in New Tab."  This will give you a chance to read the page title and see if your still curious.       
 3) If the tab you opened says "Go To Sleep!" Close it WITHOUT LOOKING AT IT and thank god you didn't have to hire a therapist.       
 4) If it says anything other than that, be wary.  Seriously, brace yourself because it's probably some other scary shit or the grossest most fucked up kind of porn imaginable.    
   
 Note:  If whatever you clicked on turns out to just be spam, thank god because it could be so, SSOOOO much worse.

- Spitfire (youtube.com/SpitfireRhymes)

This is sort of like the challenge I took in Portal 2 to make at least 5 puzzles that are all condensed into 3x3x3 spaces. I got up to 8 and then ran out of ideas.

NOTHING was to be allowed outside these parameters, but I could of course bring IN blocks for surface purposes and glass-placement. Every puzzle was intended to be completely different than the last and using some sort of clever mechanism that the player had to, of course, figure out. They were all timed so that you had to KNOW what to do before doing it, but failure to accomplish the task before the timer ran out gave the player no consequence but to restart.

Some people who played them claimed that the time aspect was too difficult for some puzzles, so I remade all 8 with various modifications to fit inside of a 7x7x3 space where each corner was a puzzle. The exits lined up with the entrance of the next puzzle, so it was like doing one after the other. I made 2 of them, 4 in each, with all the original 8 puzzles being re-perfected in some small way.

I really respect the challenge you've taken on/have already accomplished and I'll do my best to watch and learn every day.
